results.title: [Remix: Hats]
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to hats and how we wear them. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring styles, shapes and fabrics of hats. Whether at the beach, riding a horse, driving a racing car or going for a swim, a fashionable head-covering is a must. Australian fashion’s best styles of hats for men, women and children from the 1930s to the 1980s are shown.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tony Agapitos, Karen Wootton, The Gadsden Family, Elenor Peach, Karen Corry, Jenny & Owen Peake, Gil Brealey & Paul Olson and John Richardson.

results.title: Flash Back: ACMI Collections Mash-up White Night 2017
results.brief_description:
‘Flash Back’, an archival mashup of films and footage from the 1940s through to the ‘80s celebrating the changing face of Australian youth identity and culture.

From rebel youth of the ‘50s, to the ‘70s counter culture revolution and the punk attitudes of the ‘80s, ‘Flash Back’ explores the changing decades through diverse subcultures and the music, fashions and cultural preoccupations that shaped them.

Image: ‘Sharpies: A Gathering’, courtesy Greg Macainsh

Our sincere thanks to filmmakers, musicians and donors for material used in this work. Full details in credits. Edited by ACMI’s Sam Mapplebeck.

results.title: Return of the Sacred Kingfisher Festival 2000
results.brief_description: Each November since the Sacred Kingfisher was seen again in the Merri Creek environment, a festival has been held at CERES Community Environment Park to celebrate the return of this native bird to the area as part of its seasonal migration. The festival, with the participation of local schools and communities, also celebrates the cleanup and revegetation of the Merri Creek environs, and the work of CERES in the Melbourne suburb of Brunswick East.

results.title: Gaps
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
results.description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
description_for_label:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: Screen worlds : Interview with Ab Rogers
results.brief_description: British designer Ab Rogers is founder and head of a multi-disciplinary studio in London ARD (Ab Rogers Desgin). Ab visited ACMI in December 2008 and the Content Development crew interviewed him in relation to his design and intent behind the Screen Worlds exhibition. He spoke about the tendering process, the challenges of designing for the Federation Square space, his overall approach to design and a brief introduction to the three sections, Emergence, Voices and Sensation.

results.title: Remembering the past and looking forward to the future
results.creator_credit: Cuong Manh Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A story of escape by boat from Vietnam to a Malaysian refugee camp, and then to Australia in 1986 where Cuong Manh Pham eventually made a new life, reuniting with his family in 1990.

results.title: A Journey to a new land
results.creator_credit: Tuan Anh Tran, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Leaving family and escaping from Vietnam in 1978 and eventually arriving in Australia by boat as a refugee, it would be six years before Tuan Anh Tran could finally be reunited with his family.

results.title: China tour
results.creator_credit: ACMI, ACMI Digital Storytelling and Si Tuan Lieng
results.brief_description: Si Tuan Lieng and his wife are retirees and have recently made an overseas trip to China. In this story he talks about his life and family, their integration into Australian society since they left Vietnam over 26 years ago and highlights of their holiday in China.

results.title: Little journey
results.creator_credit: Keith Nguyen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keith remembers little of his early years - separated from his parents and living with his grandparents. His father had been sent to a Re-education Camp and his mother had moved away. On his father’s release from the Camp the family was reunited and several years later they escaped from the hardships of Vietnam to seek a better life in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Nguyen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Keith remembers little of his early years - separated from his parents and living with his grandparents. His father had been sent to a Re-education Camp and his mother had moved away. On his father’s release from the Camp the family was reunited and several years later they escaped from the hardships of Vietnam to seek a better life in Australia.

On his father’s release from the Camp the family was reunited and several years later they escaped from the hardships of Vietnam to seek a better life in Australia.

results.title: About my dad
results.creator_credit: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.
